title: Warren Versus Trump ‘Spend Fest’ May Finally End Dollar’s Rally
text:
(Bloomberg) -- A 2020 U.S. presidential election that pits Democratic hopeful Elizabeth Warren against President Donald Trump could finally crack the dollar’s multiyear rise, according to Jefferies LLC.

Analysts are evaluating the scenario after a poll released Saturday showed Warren took the lead in Iowa, a state that plays a key role in deciding who takes on Trump.

A Warren-Trump match-up would result in “a massive spend fest on who could promise more spending than the other,” according to Brad Bechtel, the global head of foreign-exchange at Jefferies. That could further balloon the U.S. deficit -- already on track for $1 trillion -- and weaken the dollar, he said.

“Warren and Trump’s tone would be different but the end result would be the same, massive blowouts of the U.S. government budget,” Bechtel wrote in a note Tuesday. “If the market starts seeing the fiscal side under stress as a result of what the new president or continued President would do, then the USD could start to soften up, short term.”

The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index has increased in five of the past six years, and it’s up again in 2019 as the greenback beats all but two Group-of-10 currencies. Trump would probably welcome a weaker dollar. He has frequently complained that the currency’s strength is making it more difficult for U.S. manufacturers to compete abroad.

Trump said earlier this month that he’s planning another tax cut, following last year’s package. Meanwhile, Warren has proposed funneling $3 trillion toward fighting climate change.

While budget pressures would initially pressure the dollar, this will eventually support the currency, Bechtel said. “Rates would move higher and that would ultimately support the USD but in the short term you could see an extended period of USD weakness.”
